title: Decision Speed vs Quality
content: Fast decisions aren't always bad; slow decisions aren't always good. The key is matching decision speed to available time and consequence severity. High-stakes decisions with time available warrant deeper analysis. Time-critical situations demand rapid assessment with acceptable risk tolerance. Know when to think and when to act.

mcq.question: You have 60 seconds to decide whether to stop an operation due to a developing situation. What should guide your decision?

options.B: Current safety margins and rate of change

mcq.explanation: With 60 seconds, you assess current state and trajectory. Are you within safety margins? How fast is the situation developing? This determines whether you can wait or must act now.

openQuestions: How do you decide how much time you can spend on a decision?
Describe a situation where you decided too slowly or too quickly.
